title: System Autopsy
author: Rashid Azarang
summary: A facilitated diagnostic ritual designed to expose the actual structure of operational systems, not as they appear in documentation but as they function in reality. Employs tools like Hero Map, Logic Leak Trace, Tool Collapse Map, Interface Illusion Audit, and Operational Eulogy to reveal architectural patterns that support or undermine cognitive clarity.

Unlike process reviews focused on optimization, the Autopsy probes beneath surface symptoms to reveal architectural patterns that either support or undermine cognitive clarity.
whenToUse: Before initiating significant system changes or replacements
When recurring operational problems resist resolution
During post-mortems of critical incidents or failures
As part of merger/acquisition technical due diligence
When handovers between teams or individuals reveal knowledge gaps

Historical incident records and resolution patterns
Stakeholder interviews across different organizational levels

Examples of recurring problems and their workarounds
outputs: Actual system architecture as it exists in practice

Visibility into hidden dependencies and single points of failure

diagnosticTools.name: Hero Map
diagnosticTools.purpose: Identify individuals who personally hold operations together through memory, vigilance, or willpower
diagnosticTools.method: Interview team members about who they call when systems break; track escalation patterns; observe crisis response
diagnosticTools.documentation: Create a network diagram showing dependencies on specific individuals and the knowledge domains they cover
diagnosticTools.analysis: Assess whether knowledge is structurally embedded or personally dependent; identify critical expertise requiring externalization

diagnosticTools.name: Logic Leak Trace
diagnosticTools.purpose: Locate where a system's actual logic resides (in code, dashboards, spreadsheets, or minds)
diagnosticTools.method: Follow the decision-making path for key operational processes; identify where rules, thresholds, and calculations are defined
diagnosticTools.documentation: Map the distribution of business logic across formal and informal repositories
diagnosticTools.analysis: Evaluate consistency, accessibility, and governance of operational logic; identify opportunities for centralization

diagnosticTools.name: Tool Collapse Map
diagnosticTools.purpose: Assess critical dependencies on specific platforms or tools
diagnosticTools.method: Document which systems would catastrophically fail if a particular tool became unavailable; identify integration points and dependencies
diagnosticTools.documentation: Create a dependency matrix showing tool relationships and failure cascades
diagnosticTools.analysis: Evaluate resilience to tool failures; identify brittleness in integration patterns; assess architectural flexibility

diagnosticTools.name: Interface Illusion Audit
diagnosticTools.purpose: Contrast what dashboards appear to answer with what they actually answer
diagnosticTools.method: Test dashboard accuracy against alternative data sources; evaluate metric definitions and data lineage; assess decision-maker trust levels
diagnosticTools.documentation: Catalog discrepancies between interface promises and delivery; identify trust gaps
diagnosticTools.analysis: Evaluate where interfaces mask rather than reveal reality; identify data quality and integration issues

diagnosticTools.name: Operational Eulogy
diagnosticTools.purpose: Document capabilities that have eroded over time
diagnosticTools.method: Interview long-tenured team members about what the system used to do well but no longer does; identify lost functionality
diagnosticTools.documentation: Create a historical record of capability decay and its causes
diagnosticTools.analysis: Evaluate patterns of erosion; identify where technical or structural debt has accumulated; assess organizational memory function

integrationPhase: Synthesize findings from all diagnostic tools
Create a comprehensive map of the actual system architecture
